shortdesc.p: CWRC is an online research environment that brings together scholarly materials and digital tools.

The organization, creation, and upload of materials relies on content models. These define the parameters of a subcollection, determining is you can add a subcollection and what type of material can be added.

CWRC users have different levels of access to their projects. This ranges from non-members who can only view the materials on CWRC to project administrators who has complete control over project materials.

CWRC provides an enriched user experience no matter what type of user account you have. Features include an insite messaging system between project members and a bookmarking tool to collection your favorite materials together.
CWRC utilizes a robust search system to make the contents of the site as accessible and explorable as possible.

The Menu Bar is located at the top of any CWRC page and provides points of navigation into the CWRC site, including (from left to right): CWRC home page, Collaboratory, News, About, Projects, Help icon, Language Settings icon, Notifications icon, and Profile icon.

When you upload files into CWRC you must have a place to put them. You need subcollections or “folders” that will organize the files within a project (or “collection”). Each subcollection is assigned a policy which determines which type of files are allowed to be stored in them.

If you would like to upload a particular object to your collection, you may have to change the policy associated with your collection (depending on what you assigned to it when you created your collection).
These instructions can be used for any file upload or born digital documents.
CWRC is still in development and you may discover some bugs. Please let us know if you find an issue.

When you are approved for a CWRC account, only your name, email and password are attached to said account. Adding account details (like an image) make your account more accessible and findable for other members.
CWRC has the option to share or make your bookmark lists private. Bookmark lists are private as the default. The same steps apply if you would like to make a bookmark list private.
You can use the visualization tool, PlotIt, in CWRC. This feature works with your bookmark lists to map and date the files that you have bookmarked. For more information about using PlotIt, see

The sharing options CWRC provides depend on if you are trying to share a file or a folder. Folders can be shared to different social media sites (Facebook, etc.), while individual files can be shared to those sites as well as different CWRC projects.

CWRC-Writer provides three options for users to work with their documents. Users can view, annotate or edit documents.
CWRC-Writer provides users with the opportunity to annotate documents. This feature is only available to users who are in the same project as the document or if the document is unlocked.
To create CWRC-Writer compatible documents you can either upload well formed XML files or create a document from existing templates.

topic.title: Deleting text from the structure panel

shortdesc.p: CWRC-Writer templates open with pre-existing text. It may be easier to first delete the text (but not the tags) before adding your own text to the document.
In CWRC-Writer your documents can be edited by multiple people. The “Save and Exit” icon does as the title suggests and opens up the document for others to edit.
The validation of your XML document against the associated schema. If your document is invalid a list of errors found in the document will appear at the bottom of the page.
There is an option to change the different editor modes for your document. Editor modes control what tagging will be allowed in your document (a combination of XML and RDF).
Show tags allows you to view all the XML tags in the document.
Edit Source is for users who wish to edit the raw XML or RDF code. We do not suggest that you use this option unless you are an expert.
You can edit the TEI header in CWRC-Writer.

You can create CWRC-Writer documents in two ways, either by uploading a file or by using a pre existing template (provided by CWRC). Additionally, these options are customizable to you and your project because you select which schema to use.
The "Settings" options allow you to change the settings of your document.
There are three different tabs on the left hand side of CWRC-Writer.
At the top of the editor there is a toolbar that allows you to add, edit, and delete tags and entities.
The editor allows you to add entities to your document that include RDF and XML tags.
You can add tags within the editor by highlighting the text and right-clicking. This will bring up a list of option available to you (adding entities, structural tags, editing, etc).
CWRC-Writer provides two options to save your changes and document. The first is a general save action, but the second allows users to save and then exit the document.
Copying and pasting text into CWRC-Writer, can be achieved in two ways. The first, by highlighting text in the text area.

topic.title: Copying and pasting a single tag

shortdesc.p: Copying and pasting a tag allow you to duplicate structure and/or content with minimal effort. This acts as a type of shortcut tor producing content in you document.

Copying and pasting multiple tags within CWRC-Writer is the fastest way to build up a document. Whether you are adding poem lines or more notes, you can create entire sections of structure in a few easy steps.

topic.title: Viewing information copied from the structure panel

shortdesc.p: CWRC-Writer provides the option of looking at what you have copied in the structure panel before you need to paste it in. This allows you to make sure you have selected exactly what you wanted to work with.

topic.title: Copying and pasting entities in the editor

shortdesc.p: You can copy and paste entities in CWRC-Writer. This will let you replicate annotations entities, so that you can have multiple instances of that tag in the document (with the same contextual information).

topic.title: Adding structural tags by selecting text

shortdesc.p: In each document that you work with there is a pre-existing XML template that contains the basic tags necessary for that type of document. You can add new structural tags to the document easily.

topic.title: Adding structural tags in the structural panel

topic.title: Overview of Dynamic Table of Contexts

shortdesc.p: The Dynamic Table of Contexts (DToC) viewer is an in-browser e-reader that uses the underlying structure of a document to allow different paths through the text to be discovered when read. The corpus may be navigated via semantic tags, the index (if present), or the search function, as well as through the frequency of terms used throughout the document. DToC allows readers to "curate" the text they are reading by permitting the customization of tags, even if the text being "read" is not their own. It is also possible to make one's own DToC edition by starting from one of our templates.
The Table of Contents presents the section or chapter breakdown of your document.

topic.title: Left column of Dynamic Table of Context

shortdesc.p: This column allow users to search and browse the document through the use of key terms, tags, and word frequencies.
Please feel free to download the DToC XML template or ignore it, depending on your XML expertise and/or adventurous spirit.
DToC provides different features to share and save your document for future use.

topic.title: Navigating text in the table of contents

shortdesc.p: The Table of Contents displays terms selected from the left column, and lets users move through the text by clicking on them. This allows for in-depth exploration of terms without the trouble of scrolling through the corpus manually.
The Document Model is a deconstructed version of your document. Each section of grey lines represents a different section, chapter, or article within the document.

The text in the Reading Pane is separated into chapters, sections, or articles by the XML document. The Reading Pane loads individual sections; the entire document will not appear unless no text divisions have been embedded into the document.

topic.title: Filtering index terms, tags, and stats

shortdesc.p: The Search feature narrows down terms automatically as you type. The string of characters being entered into into the Search bar will bring up words containing that string, regardless of whether the word begins with those characters or not.

The search box is autocomplete-enabled. If you don't use that function (e.g. you continue to type your word or phrase without selecting a term from the drop down list) your search may not work if it has a spelling error, an extra space, or any other form of discrepancy with the tags and terms as they have been encoded into the document.

When you move between different tabs in the left column they will not be filtered by the Chapter you have selected in the previous column. However, when you return to the initial tab, the chapter filter will remain selected.
You can customize how you view word frequencies in DToC by different organizational headings and by how the words are displayed under those headings.

topic.title: Viewing stats by chapters and collections

shortdesc.p: You can add as many terms as you would like to your “Favorites” list, either all at once or a few at a time.
You can add context to your annotations using the "AnnotateIt" tool. For more information about signing up to “AnnotateIt” see “Login/Annotator Authentication.”
The left column has a list of the tags found in the document. You can add new tags to the list, regardless of whether they have been included in your XML document or not.

topic.title: Creating an XML document for the Dynamic Table of Contexts

shortdesc.p: In the Dynamic Table of Contexts (DToC) users can upload their own XML text. These XML documents need to be specially formatted in order to experience the full range of capabilities provided by DToC.

topic.title: Adding XML ids to your document manually

shortdesc.p: DToC uses XML ids as index locators. Every index item is associated with one or more paragraphs; their function is analogous to that of page numbers used in print indexes.

This option is best for large DToC documents. The downside of using oXygen to insert IDs is that they are not human readable. It may be worth using the tool, if you are able to use a script to transform the ID pattern.

Humanities Visualizer (HuViz) is a browser-based tool for visualing linked data.
The quickest and most intuitive way to manipulate the dataset is directly in the graph.
Working directly in the Graph using the "drag and drop" technique involves fewer steps. However, working from the Commands Tab has multiple benefits.
The Current Command box acts as a prompt to notify the user which elements need to be selected to execute a command.
To begin, choose a dataset.
Use the Select function to choose which nodes to execute a command on.
It is easy to tell the difference between Selected from Unselected nodes.
Select nodes by hand with the following steps.
The All function is used to perform actions on all nodes at the same time.
Select nodes by Set or Class using the Commands Tab.
Select nodes using the Like bar to perform a text search.
The Activate function drags nodes into the graph.
Graph nodes using the "drag and drop" method with the following steps.
The Shelve function returns nodes to the the outer ring that orbits the central graph.
Shelve nodes using the "drag and drop" method with the following steps.
The Discard function removes nodes from the central Graph or Shelf and sends them to the Discard bin.
Discard nodes using the "drag and drop" method with the following steps.
Use the Retrieve function to return only Discarded nodes to the Shelf.
Return Discarded nodes to the Shelf using the Commands Tab.
The Hide function removes nodes from the visualization.
The Pin function fixes or "pins" Graphed nodes in place.
Pin nodes using the "drag and drop" method with the following steps.
The Label function displays the node name.
In the Commands Tab, actions are automatically executed when a selected Set or Class type is combined with a Verb.
Use Reset to restore the dataset to default mode.
When two nodes in the central Graph are linked together by a line this indicates that they share a relationship. The nature of this relationship is represented as an Edge.
Edges are displayed both in the Graph and in the Commands Tab.
Snippet windows allow users to explore the relationships between nodes in more detail. In the HuViz prototype, the "snippet" of text is extracted from the source entry on the Orlando Project.
Graph nodes according to the type of connections (aka Edges) they share using the Edges of Selected Nodes bin.
Adjust the appearance of the graph using the Settings Tab.
Welcome to Plot-It. Here we describe how to get started using Plot-It and what to look out for.
The timeline displays events organized by the date they occurred. This information can be navigated two different ways, by year or by decade.
The map feature in Plot-It allows users to view the geographical information of the events found in the timeline.

To learn more information about the events, click on an icon in the timeline or map. The metadata/description for that event will appear in the text box located in the middle of Plot-It, and users are able to scroll through the information.

topic.title: View events not in the map

shortdesc.p: If an event does not have a location attached to it, then it does not appear in the map. You can view these events in alternate ways.
The user can change the way that they view the events from the timeline. The available options are a map, a list, and a grid view.
Users can search to narrow down or find a specific data point. The search function is accessed on the left side of Plot-It.

topic.title: Filter by Date of event range

shortdesc.p: The “Date of event range” allows users to adjust what events users see between a specific period of time.
Users can narrow down what type of events appear in the timeline or the map by selecting from a list on the left side of the page.
Users can filter what country events are located in, by selecting from a list on the left side of the page. This will narrow down the results in both the timeline and the map.
Users can reset both a search and searching filters in multiple ways. Once a user has reset or unselected the checkboxes, the timeline and map will re-populate with all events.
If you are not interested in using the timeline, or would like to just focus on the map/list/grid, you can hide the timeline.
If you would like to work only with the timeline, or are not interested in the map/list/grid panel, you can hide that information.
Plot-It allows users to view information in relation with its geographical and temporal location. Users can manipulate the timeline for a better view of the data points.
Users have the opportunity to view events in either the map, as a list, or in a grid.
Events are located in both the timeline and the panel below. The event metadata provides more information about the event.
Users can search to narrow down or find a specific data point. The search function is accessed on the left side of Plot-It.
